name: NewYorker
text:
The damage that comes from rising temperatures will ultimately be less telling than our collective ability to respond, Bill McKibben writes, in his latest Climate Crisis newsletter.
https://t.co/ivovSrRNss

name: NewYorker
text:
There are many reasons to doubt that the United States Postal Service is prepared to serve as a backstop for American democracy in this time of peril.
https://t.co/WGLZwAhp5D

text: New uses for pepper-spray goggles, riot shields, bulletproof vests, and more. https://t.co/Ml01cug4MB

name: NewYorker
text: On the case of Hannah Upp, who suffered from dissociative fugues, a rare condition in which people lose access to their memory and personal identity. https://t.co/dwHGHMHiEs

name: NewYorker
text:
Why J. F. K.’s book “Profiles in Courage,” from 1956, works as a lesson in the dangers of historical misunderstanding.

name: NewYorker
text: Residents of Cody, Wyoming—where Kanye West has a ranch—compare notes on Michelle Tidball, the local mystic who works in a dentist’s office and says she can communicate with God. https://t.co/dpSnO8bFdP

name: NewYorker
text: A first vaccine, while a welcome tool in fighting COVID-19, may turn out to be of limited use. The lesson learned from AIDS is the value of building a scientific infrastructure beyond a vaccine. https://t.co/WKh648qSLG

name: NewYorker
text: In Daily Shouts, @lizzzzzielogan prepares to embrace the world in its fullness. https://t.co/TbaNXJloiB

name: NewYorker
text: When a Trump flotilla (or “Trumptilla”) swarmed into town, its organizers hoped it would “make liberals cry.” The more immediate effect was to freak out the Coast Guard. https://t.co/yAuDL4kDW4

name: NewYorker
text: “He believed, truly, that he would be exonerated. How could he not be?” Listen to Emma Cline read her new short story. https://t.co/Kb9P6u7Suy

name: NewYorker
text: “If there is anything that I hope we achieve in the midst of this unprecedented moment in American history, it’s that we use this moment to rethink . . . some of the basic tenets and institutions of American society.” An interview with Bernie Sanders. https://t.co/NjSbrB1BaD

name: NewYorker
text: To protect worker health and reduce corporate liability, many companies will have no choice but to allow significantly more telework for months or perhaps years to come. Is it finally time to embrace remote office work? https://t.co/3ItBlO2vde

name: NewYorker
text: The toppling of a statue of a slave trader in Bristol, along with a series of Black Lives Matter protests that have taken place across the U.K. in recent weeks, has revived a long-simmering debate over monuments to Britain’s past. https://t.co/0zpYmC0z8W

name: NewYorker
text: A cartoon by Jody Zellman. https://t.co/M52gZs0WAp https://t.co/k8uNUasYl5

name: NewYorker
text: The story of Emily Brontë, who was born on this day in 1818, and her sisters has long been one of sensational legend. The truth is less grim—but more beguiling. https://t.co/lzHTg3ty1T

name: NewYorker
text: After appearing in “Taxi Driver,” Steven Prince came to occupy a space somewhere between personal assistant, emotional-support dog, and chief of security in Martin Scorsese’s increasingly nocturnal and chaotic world. https://t.co/2Vubzmykaf

text: Don’t forget to wipe down the machine. https://t.co/S4CQkPccLg https://t.co/Sur0hSCmFE

name: NewYorker
text: Are the bras from startups with inescapable social-media advertisements any different from the bras we've been wearing (or not wearing) forever? Patricia Marx reviews nine of them. https://t.co/M2rQcsl53K

name: NewYorker
text: "I will sleep beside my husband holding him in my arms, not strong arms, in fact, rather weak arms, which nonetheless can be made to behave as if they were strong." New flash fiction by @JoyceCarolOates. https://t.co/QvQaRm03Gj

name: NewYorker
text: "You watch “Law & Order” on a TV at the laundromat while you wait for the towels to finish drying." https://t.co/3i2ol3MVTW

name: NewYorker
text: "Recently, I have taken my shirt off twice while video chatting," Patricia Marx writes. "No, I’m not that starved for excitement during quarantine. In both cases, I was being fitted for a bra." https://t.co/9SLcIBw41p

name: NewYorker
text: As tuberculosis shaped modernism, so COVID-19 and our collective experience of staying inside for months on end will influence architecture’s near future, @chaykak writes. https://t.co/ag34yZckbU
